ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We mostly just met in regular online seminars.
We met for 75 minutes, twice a week for a Zoom seminar.
Class was recorded if a student had to miss discussion for some reason (which was not frequent). Professor Bakker was very accommodating and reasonable.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed new skills in Attic and Doric Greek (especially in understanding choral meters, etc.) and in analyzing texts in their original language.
I improved my knowledge of Attic and Doric Greek. I gained a deep understanding of Sophocles' Antigone and its reception.

I gained proficiency in reading Greek and learned quite a bit of background knowledge about the context of Antigone's time. Most notably, Professor Bakker help improved my grammatical understanding of the Greek language, and he helped unlock a lot of philological depth to the text.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was terrific. All of the readings were interesting, the Greek was very engaging, and class meetings were awesome.

We managed to read every line of the play in Greek very carefully. Sometimes it felt like the heavy linguistic focus meant that our discussions were secondary/of less importance. Particularly at the end of the course, we ran out of time to discuss our English readings.

The repetitiveness of class is a weakness of this course--by the 14th seminar or so, each class begins to feel similar, and we almost get lost in the thick of the play. But conversely, the strength is studying a play this closely. My favorite strength about this course is how deep we went into the Greek language, and we always connected meaning to the text itself.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was by far the best integrated for COVID-19. I think some other professors tried too hard to add new features which didn't work, whereas Professor Bakker did an excellent job of making our meetings feel like regular (and excellent) class gatherings.

We took our quizzes via Canvas outside of class, which worked well. Professor Bakker also screen-shared relevant handouts. When students had to miss a class, he recorded the seminar, which was helpful. Professor Bakker also frequently asked us for tips and strategies.

I am glad that the class was synchronous, and it allowed for a discussion that would have been very similar to class. Perhaps an occasional screen share or blackboard could have been helpful, but this class was run about as well as an online class can be.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend this class. I have developed such an appreciation for Antigone (and Greek tragedy in general) and its tremendous literary, social, and political complexities. It is seriously one of the best courses I've taken at Yale, and I would recommend it to anyone with the requisite skills in Greek.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in Antigone, Sophocles, Greek tragedy, or Attic Greek. Antigone has had many fascinating political, philosophical and literary incarnations and reading the play so thoroughly in the original made me aware of many dynamics I hadn't seen when I read the play in English. Our occasional forays into reception and secondary literature were also interesting, though they didn't inform most of our classwork; if your main interest isn't in Greek but rather in the ideas of Antigone, you might feel frustrated because we spent more time on deictic pronouns, for example, than on Jean Anouilh. But for anyone who loves/wants to improve their Greek and is interested in Antigone herself, Antigone the play, or Greek itself, the balance between language and ideas will not disappoint. The final paper gives you a bit of space to really think for yourself on the (a) meaning(s) of the play  I think you could consider the implications of Antigone very well on your own time, but analyzing Sophocles' language on your own is significantly more challenging.

I would strongly recommend this course to any student who already has a firm grasp of Ancient Greek but wishes to push their understanding of the language even further. Professor Bakker will make a student who feels confident in their Greek abilities realize that they have so much farther to go, but he does so in a supportive, never condescending way. For any who either want to major in Greek or just love the language, I strongly recommend this course. I would NOT recommend this course to someone who is somewhat interested in Ancient Greek language but prefers studying its culture and reception. You will find the Greek very difficult and demanding.
